item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Initial Assessment
item.description:
This Beogram 8002 turntable, sent from California, is the next restoration project. I prefer working on the same type of audio equipment consecutively because it minimizes workbench setup time. The owner followed our packing advice and packaged the turntable very well, using double boxes and protective foam. The turntable arrived without damage. Upon opening, I noticed the metal tonearm lid wouldn’t stay up. The part that connects to the hinge with damping grease was detached, a problem I haven’t encountered before...

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Checking the Forward/Reverse Scanning LDR Devices
item.description:
My previous work on this Beogram left me concerned about a potential issue with one of the forward/reverse scanning LDRs (Light Dependent Resistors). Testing the resistance of both LDRs with +15 VDC on the light source, I noticed a significant difference between them, leading me to believe one was faulty. However, upon removing and re-testing them, the resistance values were much closer. It’s important to note that my testing method involved a simple setup with an LED work light as a light source...

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Capacitor Replacement
item.description:
In this Beogram 8002 turntable restoration, I began by replacing the capacitors and the phono muting relay. I started with the two electrolytic capacitors on the floating chassis, which are part of the +5 VDC power supply regulation. item.description:

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Service Manual Adjustments and Record Play Test
item.description:
To complete the remaining service manual adjustments, the platter motor connector needs to be disconnected for both the tracking force and tracking sensor adjustments. To adjust the tracking force, an MMC phono cartridge is required, and it’s recommended to set the sliding tracking force knob to 1 gram. With the platter motor disconnected, the tonearm can be placed over the stationary platter. A tracking force scale is used to measure the cartridge’s tracking force, aiming for a reading of 1 gram...

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Oscilloscope Measurements
item.description:
This document summarizes the functional testing performed on a Beogram 8002 turntable, using oscilloscope captures of critical signals as a reference for comparison with other Beogram 8002 turntables. The testing involved connecting test leads to six key points on the Beogram 8002’s main board: Position Sensor 1, Position Sensor 2, Detector Arm, Speed Sensor, Servo Motor Forward, and Servo Motor Reverse.
